steps.title: Place the fleshy side of your palm lightly on the strings.
steps.content: Place the fleshy side of your palm lightly on the strings. Pretend you're karate-chopping the strings. Don't actually hit them, but that shows you what part of your hand should be hitting the strings. It should be the outside of your palm. [3] X Research source When you first put your hand down, it should be perpendicular to the strings, not laying flat against them. Slide the hand back as close to the bridge as you can-- this makes it easier to learn.

steps.title: Keeping your palm down on the strings, strum normally.
steps.content: Keeping your palm down on the strings, strum normally. Use your fingers and light wrist movement to strum while still keeping everything muted. You want to work on keeping the same weight on the strings as you strum, moving only up and down, not against the strings, as you pick. It is often easiest to start by just picking one string. As you get used to keeping it palm muted, play a two-string chord, then a three, and onward.

steps.title: Adjust the pressure of your palm to adjust your sound.
steps.content: Adjust the pressure of your palm to adjust your sound. A lot of palm muting is about the feel on the strings, since the actual skill is not very hard. The harder you press, the less you'll hear the note of the string and more you'll hear a dampened, percussive sound. If you are too light you'll just hear buzzing as the strings struggle to move. The perfect sound is a deadened, but still melodic, note that ends quickly after you strum it. [4] X Research source With dampening, you should be able to hear the pitch when you pick the string. Try picking the strings one at time to make sure you can hear all the proper pitches rather than a dead plucking sound. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Experiment with hand position.
steps.content: Experiment with hand position. You can change how much your hand dampens the sound by moving it back and forth on the strings. Moving closer to the fretboard dampens the sound more. [6] X Research source However, as noted, you should keep your hand as close to the bridge as possible if you still want to hear pitch.

steps.title: Adjust your hands to sound certain notes.
steps.content: Adjust your hands to sound certain notes. If you want the first string to sound, lift off that part of your hand. You can test to make sure it's sounding correctly by strumming it. Practice lifting off each string in order. Once you've mastered the technique, you can control which strings are dampened and which strings are not. [7] X Research source You'll be lifting from your wrist, rather than from your fingers. You can curl your wrist up and down to open up or mute certain strings with some practice.

steps.title: Tune into the bridge pickups of your electric guitar.
steps.content: Tune into the bridge pickups of your electric guitar. Since you're picking and muting near the bridge, these pickups will get the best, thickest sound for you. For a more distorted, buzzy sound, use the neck pickups.

steps.title: Use humbucker pickups whenever possible.
steps.content: Use humbucker pickups whenever possible. These pickups will grab a lot of that deep, chunky tone that you want when palm muting.

steps.title: Work on moving in and out of palm muting mid strum.
steps.content: Work on moving in and out of palm muting mid strum. Listen to old Green Day tracks, for example. They are simple chords and structures, but the ability to go quickly from palm muted to open strings allows him to texture and layer the guitar part uniquely. Learn to start palm muting, then slowly raising your palm off. Become your guitars volume knob, switching fluidly.
